Author: VonGeisler

Comment: BC and Nunavut are new to the US Booze Ban, starting May 7th!  They were the last of the provinces and territories to officially ban US produced alcohol.              So while those two new provinces make news, it’s also time for the first quarterly reports. Most bans  started towards the end of February to mid-March, so those second earnings will be most telling. And while we tend to call it a “US Alcohol Ban,” it really is a “US *Produced* Alcohol Ban.” Provinces have been allowing US-owned brands that are “Produced in Canada.” So the ban is particularly bad for bourbon producers as it must be made in Kentucky to be called bourbon.              For clarity: There also isn’t a *law* banning US produced alcohol. The bans have been put in place by the provinces, who control the import of liquor into their provinces:         - In Alberta and BC, both control boards have suspended new imports and are warehousing *their* existing stock. Independent retailers can sell existing stock but cannot place new orders.                - Saskatchewan initially banned all US alcohol products, but has since loosened its ban to align with other provinces to allow *Canadian Produced* alcohol (which mostly affects beer).           - Ontario and Quebec sell liquor exclusively through their liquor control board stores, the LCBO and SAQ. So both Ontario and Quebec had the ability to “pull” liquor from the shelves, because they own them. Restaurants won’t be able to restock once sold out, same with the independent beer/wine retailers.           -  US produced alcohol is also banned in Yukon, Northwest Territories and the Maritimes and they appear to operate similar to Alberta and BC, where independent stores with existing stock are free to sell stock but can’t restock.          - Nunavut also just joined the ban on Tuesday!
